query: Are there ants of genus Lasius?

topRanked.articleTitle: Comparison of Coleoptera emergent from various decay classes of downed coarse woody debris in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, USA
topRanked.articleAuthor: Ferro, Michael L., Gimmel, Matthew L., Harms, Kyle E. & Carlton, Christopher E.

images.captionText: Figures 63â€“68. Habitus images. 63) Thoracophorus costalis (Erichson) (Staphylinidae: Osoriinae). 64) Adranes lecontei Brendel (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae). 65) Batrisodes sp. (female) (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae). 66) Leptoplectus pertenuis (Casey) (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae). 67) Pycnoplectus sp. (female) (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae). 68) Sonoma sp. (female) (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae).

response.answer: Yes, the genus Lasius includes several species of ants that are known to inhabit nests of Lasius spp. ants, including Pselaphinae Adranes lecontei Brendel. These ants are obligate myrmecophiles and feed on fluids obtained from their adult and immature hosts.
